title: I'm honestly appalled by the state of player behavior analysis at Riot
body: Currently, players are more likely to be banned for saying things like "please report playerX for trolling" than actually trolling. Why the fuck does Riot allow this? The biggest problem is that players understand how to game this ridiculous system and they will play the victim and look for offense in the minutest of shit in order to justify a report of a player that they simply don't like or who "wronged" them in game or otherwise damaged their ego. I know I'm guilty of this, and now that I am able to reflect on it after the fact, it's fucking bullshit. The worst part is that I didn't do this consciously, meaning that this kind of response is basically a reflex. It needs to stop. Riot needs to bring back the Tribunal so that actual people can determine whether or not a report was submitted in good faith or just to mend the ego of a butthurt player.

replies.body:
Except none of that matters, because being reported only triggers a review, it has absolutely no effect on your chances of being punished.

Dont feed the trolls.

Every hear the expression "if you throw enough dirt something will stick"? The fact is that Riot is more than willing to ban for very minor stuff, things that any rational person would not consider even report worthy. But because people know this, they will report at the drop of a hat, knowing that even if the player they are reporting didn't really do anything wrong, they will trigger a review that might turn up something else. Example: player gets pissy because the jungler didn't gank, so player reports the jungler for verbal abuse just because. The review reveals that the jungler said "fuck you" to someone in that game. Jungler now has his first strike towards a punishment, even though he wasn't actually toxic at all. Obviously this is an oversimplification, but the principle remains. 

I have personally been banned for this exact reason. Someone thought I was trolling by playing pantheon support, when in fact I was just trying to make my autofill support game a bit more fun by picking something unconventional. Turns out that during that game, I announced in all chat that this player was being abusive toward me in chat (which was true) and I asked that they report him (I know this doesn't really help, but it makes me feel better to know that I at least have people on my side). Kid report me, and boom, the "please report..." in /all chat shows up in my reform card.

>Riot is more than willing to ban for very minor stuff, things that any _rational person_ would not consider even report worthy.

http://i.imgur.com/YBErqY9.jpg[/img]

That's your problem, right there. You aren't the sole judge of what is and is not "rational". The standards are set by the community, have been for a long time and are highly consistent.

Moreover, you're just wrong about how the IFS works. You either have to be _highly_ toxic or _frequently_ toxic - or both, if you really want to trash your account.

Post that reform card and we'll talk.

Because "please report X" is harassment and serves no purpose. It makes no difference how many people report someone, so it is simply a form of abuse and is always negative and unneeded.

There is no reason to run your mouth, behave like a mature, decently educated individual or go play roblox.

ha·rass·ment
həˈrasmənt,ˈherəsmənt/
noun
aggressive pressure or intimidation.

Isn't harassment by this definition. I am not being aggressive. Assertive, perhaps, but there is a definitive difference here. And obviously I'm not using intimidation, I don't even see how this would be possible without the use of actual threats, which is frankly rare, even in this community.

And the purpose it serves is purely psychological, but this doesn't make it any less valid. No one likes to be made to feel victimized, but this is exactly what Riot requires of its playerbase to avoid running afoul of the ban bot.

>behave like a mature, decently educated individual or go play roblox.

Classic. This statement right here is honestly more toxic than most things I see in game. You are making a targeted attack on both my maturity and my intelligence in order to discredit me and my opinions, which by the way are not wrong in any capacity, just different from your own. Not to get all political in here, but it was statements such as this coming from the Liberal camp that ultimately put Donald Trump in the White House.

Semantics are meaningless. You cannot escape reality with them.

What put donald trump in the whitehouse was a mixture of delusion and people denying reality in favor of comfortable lies, not that it is in any way related to riot games punishing people for running their mouths.


Everyone has two choices: Behave, or get banned.
There are no other options, no illogical semantical arguments allowed or cared about, no excuses for passive-aggressive bratty behavior and veiled insults.

There is no argument of semantics here. It is an argument of basic definitions. Riot defines "harassment" as literally whatever the hell they want to ban people for, which is a blatant abuse of power.

Logs or gtfo, kid.

I bet anyone who is not you will find all sorts of punishment-worthy offenses in them, giving your horrible attitude issues and arrogance.

Roughly 90% of this community are oversensitive pussies, and that is the problem I'm fighting. Ofc you guys will find "punishment-worthy offenses" because in this game, offense is only taken, never given.

Logs or GTFO.

Your attitude is that of an angry, arrogant brat, so i expect you got punished for being one.
Your personal opinions of what is acceptable behavior may not match the standards expected by mature, adult players, and in this case, you can conform or get out - you do not get personal exceptions.
Arrogant? Perhaps. Angry? Sure. Correct? Most definitely.

That would be the arrogance talking.
Typically when everyone but you agrees you are wrong, it is because you are wrong, not that you will accept that. It will probably make life difficult.
You think I'm the only one that thinks this? O deer, please do not interact with real people in the real world. You'll be very unpleasantly surprised...

{{sticker:zombie-brand-clap}}

I make a habit of not interacting with trash unless absolutely required.

I have no idea who you are, you look like some trash that got mad a few weeks ago and is interestingly _still_ mad.

I was hoping it was something important. Please check how much you care and consider not caring.

Just one thing.

The reason that fishing for reports is considered harrassment is becuase it is unnecessary. 

_You can report them yourself and that will be the end of it._

Additional reports do nothing, this is why they discourage this.

"Fishing for reports" as you call it is more for the psychological benefit of knowing other people are on your side. Also, please read the actual definition of harassment. Lack of necessity does NOT make something harassment. Harassment has to be very much an intentional act designed to pressure or intimidate. This is simply not harassment.

Hmm.

Do you think this counts as a necro?

In any case, it's unnecessary.

And please cite for me any source that defines "harassment" as unnecessary conduct. Communication in any capacity is deemed "unnecessary" by Riot games themselves, ergo, by your definition, to use the chat function in any capacity must therefore be harassment. See how that's pretty fked up?

No...

I just see you overthinking, overreacting, and trying to create one giant overall rule that covers everything.

That's fine and dandy, but realize that in situations like this, generalizations are almost never a good thing. It's almost always a case-by-case basis.

In issues of player behavior, where each person is different, there is no one-size-fits-all rule. It would be convenient, and it would make things easier, but that isn't how it works.

Overthinking??? The whole fucking point of this is that retaliation in this case is a knee-jerk reaction to toxicity. There is literally 0 thinking involved because it's just a reaction. Your failure to understand differing mentalities is bordering on bigotry.

Right. It takes no thought to type something, then hit enter...

By the way, is bigot the new word you're going to try to undermine my argument?

Did I call you a bigot? Nope. I told you that you were trying to make a one size fits all rule for player behavior. It doesn't work that way.

Why don't you try addressing that?
Bigot is a word that means overt intolerance of the viewpoints of others, which you very clearly display here.

Stay on topic.

If you are going to take your bloody time responding, have the courtesy of addressing the main issue.

You want a general rule for policing player behavior. It doesn't work this way.

You refuse to take responsibility for the things you type in chat. The real world expects you to take responsibility.

And as for your viewpoint, I am stating that it is flawed. You have given no convicing argument otherwise.

I am only tolorating its exsistence, but not its ideals.

This situation is not analogous to what happened in game.
>someone walks up to you with a gun and declares that they are going to kill you.
 
While an immediate response would be seen in either situation, In game, you were not put into physical, life-threatening danger. The situation you put forward has no parallel in the game.

Why not take your in-game situation and apply that to real life?

You should post your chat logs, and I think that would clear up a lot of the misunderstandings you suggest we all have about player behavior.

>The worst part is that I didn't do this consciously, meaning that this kind of response is basically a reflex.

If you mastered not making in your pants, you can overcome this. 

>Riot needs to bring back the Tribunal so that actual people can determine whether or not a report was submitted in good faith or just to mend the ego of a butthurt player.

The Tribunal was always more strict than Riot expected, sometimes by as much as 9%. You should be careful what you wish for.

>sometimes by as much as 9%

O holy arbiter please enlighten me, for I am but a mere player and could never see the light as you do. How might I also be able to place such exact statistical quantities on these strictly qualitative observations?

...oh wait, you can't offer this explanation? ya, I thought so. Fact is, this is another way Riot warps statistics to keep us players in the dark as to how they actually do things. There is absolutely no way to measure the "strictness" of the Tribunal, nor is there even a way to qualitatively measure levels of toxicity, as toxicity is a strictly qualitative observation and therefore cannot be measured in any capacity. Perhaps the Tribunal was stricter than Riot believed it would be, but it is nowhere near as strict as the ban bot is now, ESPECIALLY with regard to players with flagged accounts, regardless of the efforts take to reform (I have firsthand knowledge of this). 

Also, and this is critically important: the Tribunal was given the ENTIRE chat log for both teams throughout the entire game. The ban bot only reviews the reported player's chat. This means that the new system entirely disregards the context of the reported player's chat. And before you tote the party line (which I can feel you typing already) that "you and you alone are responsible for your actions, therefore context doesn't matter", please enlighten me again as to why in actual courts of law judges and juries are presented with all available evidence in order to come to a verdict. Could it be that the actual justice system realizes that the context in which an act was committed may be just as important as the act itself? Do you really think you (and Riot Games by extension) understand justice better than the United States Department of Justice?

Finally
>If you mastered not making in your pants, you can overcome this.

How very self-righteous of you. You have no idea what kind of person I am, and frankly, anyone who doesn't get upset, frustrated, and even downright angry when people deliberately waste their time and effort (which is exactly what trolling does) clearly has no passion. This is the exact statement I have read from so many people on these forums in various other posts regarding this general topic, and to all of these people, I ask the following: have you ever played a real sport in your life ever? I ask this rhetorically, of course, because if you had actually played a real sport at even a   minor competitive level (ie Little League baseball) you would NEVER make these kinds of assumptions regarding the competitive mindset.

The 9% was common knowledge back in the TBI days. I'm not going to go back for the citations, because it's clear you won't listen.

> please enlighten me again as to why in actual courts of law judges and juries are presented with all available evidence in order to come to a verdict.

Because this isn't a court of law. You signed an agreement with Riot and then broke the terms of that agreement. If you get into a shouting match in a theater, they're not going to give a rat's ass about "context." You're getting thrown out regardless. That same principle applies here.

> I ask the following: have you ever played a real sport in your life ever?

Yes, I lettered in football, track and cycling in high school. I also did some wrestling, but I was super small until I hit my growth spurt (117# as a sophomore), so there wasn't much competition there and I did other things after I grew. These days I don't have much time, but I do charity races when I get the chance. 

As for competitive mindset, you're so far off base it's not even funny. I'm a candidate master with the FIDE and was once ranked in the top 200 worldwide at professional MtG. I also play League, of course. I'm just getting into ranked because I can finally pretty much guarantee getting the role I want. I'm 2 - 2 right now. I would have been 7-3, but I was slow-rolling it and got clipped by the reset.

>How very self-righteous of you.

Absolutely. Then again, I think I have earned the right to be, considering that I have actually mastered being able to be as competitive as I am and still maintain control of myself when things go wrong.

>The 9% was common knowledge back in the TBI days. I'm not going to go back for the citations, because it's clear you won't listen.

Classic. The "trust me, because you're an idiot" argument. If you can't provide a means to explain how such information can be measured QUANTITATIVELY (that means with numbers) then it is by definition a subjective statement at best, a false statistic at worst. Note: I'm not saying that the Tribunal was more or less strict than predicted, I'm merely saying that you're assertion of such an exact statistic is bullshit. However, regardless of the strictness of the original Tribunal, the current system is FAR stricter, in that PEOPLE ARE BEING PERMANENTLY SUSPENDED FOR ACTIONS THAT WOULD PREVIOUSLY ONLY GET THEM CHAT RESTRICTED. That is the point of the escalating punishments, and it's borderline unethical. Please address my whole argument, not just the parts for which you have a witty retort.

>Yes, I lettered in football, track and cycling in high school. I also did some wrestling, but I was super small until I hit my growth spurt (117# as a sophomore), so there wasn't much competition there and I did other things after I grew. These days I don't have much time, but I do charity races when I get the chance.

Aaaand the copy/paste response for whenever I call people out on this. It's always football, why do people also go for football? It's as if they think football will get them more respect. Ok, here we go, assuming you did play football, not having a "win at all costs" attitude pretty much gets you universally hated and almost exclusively benched. I learned this hard way when I played in middle school and decided to skip the winter conditioning sessions so I could join a club. BIG mistake for my football "career", and one that took me years to live down. As for your other sports, they are all individual competitions. There is a very different mindset required when you can only depend on yourself to win. Now I fully understand that many high school track meets will combine scores and such to determine which team "won" the meet, but even still, you are not competing in your even with a team (unless you are running a relay, but even still, the team dynamic is not the same as traditional "team" sports).

And no one has the right to be self-righteous. You don't earn that for being a Riot poster child. A pretentious ass is still a pretentious ass, regardless of your title.

I'm not self-righteous because I'm a volunteer. I'm self-righteous because I'm confident in myself. I'm not pretending to anything. I'm often right because I take the time to educate myself and because I know the limits of my knowledge and intelligence. Self-righteousness and arrogance are two different things. 

But, I get that you have to paint me as an asshole because yours is the child's argument: _You're wrong and you lie._ That's fine.

That being said, let's talk football. I come from a very large family of craftsmen and women. My dad was a tool-and-die maker. I grew up on a farm. As you can imagine, my family is big into sports. My mom was a semi-professional tennis player. My dad was a wrestler.

Dad was also into baseball. All through my childhood, we would go to a half-dozen games a year at Wrigley Field. I can't stand the sport, however. My lady friend (at my age, divorces and blended families are a reality, so exact terminology is a delicate thing) is a huge Tigers fan, but that's not a thing we do together.

And you're absolutely right that I was drawn to cycling and track because of the solitude. It's the same reason I have a high appreciation for tennis - even as I suck at it. My maternal grandfather, however, was into football. His family came from Wisconsin, so we would combine a visit with seeing the Packers play. I have many fond memories of huddling under a huge blanket with him, listening to the deep rumble of his play-by-play.

Then he got cancer. This being the 70's and my grandfather coming from a generation where men just didn't go to the hospital for "trivial pains", by the time he was diagnosed, it had spread everywhere. Two months later, my parents snuck me into the hospital to say goodbye. As we watched him go, I was struck by how withered he was. He had been such a large, vibrant man, always ready with a smile and a hug. Later, as the family sat shivas, my grandmother showedme his Packers jacket and hat as she stored them away, telling me that I would grow into them eventually.

Fast forward to high school, where I was the second-smallest boy in my class. I so desperately wanted to fit in and sports was the way to do it. I got on the JV team my freshman year, mostly out of sheer determination and discipline. Coach was a big fan of "playing cold", which sometimes meant literally. Everything was punished with laps. Drop a pass? Laps. Miss a tackle? Laps. Use profanity anywhere in school and coach heard about it? More laps.

Now, the laps didn't count unless coach saw them, so that sometimes meant getting to school before sunrise and doing them - in t-shirt and gym shorts in Michigan winter - while he sat there, not-so-surreptitiously sipping from a flask. I have a smart mouth, so I did a LOT of laps.

I made varsity my sophomore year because I was fast, tenacious and I ran my routes precisely. I played as though I had something to prove - because I did. Growing up watching Walter Payton put his shoulder down and drive through safeties, I did that too and started to get a reputation as someone to be feared. Double-teams became common, as did driving me into the turf on as many tackles as possible. I played with dislocated fingers, because that's what you do when you come from a farm, born to middle-class parents who got there by never giving up, going through life as the small, smart kid. That's what you do when perfection is the only way to be seen.

I got my growth spurt that summer and put on twenty pounds of muscle. I scored five touchdowns against our division rival, a much larger school with much larger players, sending us to state for the first time in a decade. After that game, I came home to find that jacket and hat on my bed, along with a note that said, "I guess you're big enough now."

I still have the hat, though I don't wear it any more. It sits on my dresser with some other memories. The jacket I wore until it basically fell apart. My mom cut out the logo and made it into a blankie for my niece, who loved it until it didn't make it out of the washer.

So, when your argument is that I couldn't have played football because of some bullshit idea you have in your head, my only response is to tell you to [redacted], which is something I can say here because this isn't in-game.

Definition of self–righteous
:  convinced of one's own righteousness especially in contrast with the actions and beliefs of others :  narrow-mindedly moralistic

As to the larger discussion, I continue to reject the notion that you can't control what you type. Tourette's of the keyboard is not a thing.

LOL you fail miserably to understand that people might have different mentalities than you, and this is the single worst thing that Riot does. People do not like being victimized, fact. When people are victimized, they have varying responses, also fact. Clearly, you are of the mentality (as is Riot) that when a person is victimized, they should take it up the ass, and the report it to the proper authorities later. I am of the mindset that if someone attacks me, I will defend myself. That's who I am, I don't take shit from people unless they actually have the right to give me shit (ie a boss who is scolding me for less-than-satisfactory work, etc). For some reason, Riot's "PhD psychologists" that they have on the behavioral analysis team fail to see the actual psychology behind retaliation. It makes you feel as though you have some semblance of control over the situation. One does not need an advanced degree to understand these basic principles, so I sincerely question the qualifications of these "PhDs".

>I am of the mindset that if someone attacks me, I will defend myself.

You're not defending anything but your ego, which no one but you cares about. It's not like there's a "punch target player in the nose" macro.

>Clearly, you are of the mentality (as is Riot) that when a person is victimized, they should take it up the ass, and the report it to the proper authorities later.

Whoa there, bucko. You're not being "victimized." You are choosing to act out in a private venue despite explicit instructions to the contrary. I have been to bowling alleys with some tough sons of bitches and the same rules apply there as they do in League: _get in a shouting match, get thrown out_.
Of course im defending my fucking ego kid, this doesnt make it any less of a defense. Also, in your example the potential for actual violence is very real, not so in this game.

Oh, I'm absolutely rejecting your ideas. That's my prerogative as someone who disagrees with you. What you misunderstand is that I have never been biased against you or your ideas. I read what you wrote - and continue to do so, by the way - and responded directly to it each time, even including a very heartfelt memory of losing my grandfather to cancer. You still haven't apologized for calling me a liar, by the way. 

>Fact: you are intolerant to people different from you. 

Disagreement is not intolerance. What you are attempting is erasure via ad hominem. If you can paint me as the bad guy, my ideas can be ignored. Well, I'm not going away and this line of attack doesn't work with me, so maybe try something else?

>The real world does not enforce the same behavioral principles as Riot, and that puts Riot games staunchly in opposition of actual mentality.

I'm Jewish, _so the house next door doesn't enforce the same behavioral principles as mine._ Nicest pagans you ever met, by the by. The point is that our different values don't make our values irrelevant in our own homes.

Truth is, the world is a patchwork of values and social mores.  Saying "Riot is wrong because they're not consistent with group X" is pretty silly when there are millions of groups out there. 

>In the real world, if someone criticizes you, you don't get to call the police and have them arrested. But Riot does essentially just this.

Riot doesn't do that at all. You can't go to prison for breaking the Summoner's Code. Riot doesn't have local ordinances to force you to mow your lawn or paint your fence.

What they do have is a contract you signed stating that you will and will not do certain things. One of those things is not being a jerk to other players, regardless of how much you think you were provoked.

It is super simple. 

Don't bite/respond ECT. 


Since you point how easy it is to be reported then don't respond in kind. Jerks on your team? Mute them and likewise for the other team. It just boils down to ego and the inability to let it roll off your back.

 If someone says something abusive or untrue, you can always respond in a positive way, by clarifying. If the next response is neg then mute.


It's my understanding that it's repetitive reports that get a person in trouble. It logically follows if you are getting a ban from Riot, it is because you are a repeat offender.

This is equivalent to telling a person who defended him/herself from physical violence to simply "avoid getting assaulted". It's a kneejerk reaction, and it in the case of League, more psychologically motivated than anything else. If someone is harassing you, and you are literally forced to take it up the ass and be a victim (which is what Riot demands you do) it just makes you feel like shit. Standing up for yourself and fighting back at the very least makes you feel like less victimized and more in control of your own situation instead of letting some fuckwad control you. And before you say "just report them, they'll get banned" well, maybe they will. Maybe they'll get banned. Or maybe (and more likely) your report will NOT be the one to trigger the ban. Or maybe they aren't toxic with enough frequency to get a ban (this is the case of people who  have never been banned, mind you. If your account is flagged, it doesn't matter. 3 toxic games in any duration of time = next punishment, my most recent reform ticket included games that were literally months apart). Regardless of reason, it is very unlikely that you will get that glorious notification that they were banned, meaning that you just took it up the ass for literally no reason, and that feels like shit.

But, you're letting them control you. That's what these others are trying to tell you. Being in charge of your own response and your own actions is control. That shows power. Mindlessly biting at a stimulus is an animal response, like a dog.

When a mosquito buzzes by your ear, you either kill it, or let it go. No worries. Flamers in the game are little bugs. Either report them or let them go. No worries.

Answer me this: if someone is bullying your kid at school, are you going to tell him to take it and then tell his teachers every time someone says boo to him? Or are you going to tell him to stand up for himself. One of these things will make him hated just about until he graduates highschool, the other might just garner him some respect and actually make the bullying stop.

The argument you Riot fanboys use to counter me literally did not exist until Riot themselves quite literally invented it. If someone bullied you, you defended yourself appropriately, and that was that. Not until Riot were people actually encouraged to take it up the ass, and NEVER were the victims punished for defending themselves. This is a uniquely Riot Games stance on the subject. Please kindly introduce yourself to the real world.

When I was young, I followed your line of thinking. I learned Kung-Fu. I could beat any one of them. I could beat any two of them. I could beat any four of them. Against eight, I could avoid being injured and wear them down till an authority figure came in to view and caused them to disperse. They never stopped. They never respected me.

Now, my daughter: when someone threatens to burn a cross in our yard, kill her and hide the body.... That is a criminal offense. Report it to the teachers and the police. They get expelled and sent to juvenile hall. Amazingly, it's difficult for someone to bully her when they're in prison. If she doesn't report it, there is absolutely nothing we could do about the situation. If she threatened them back, then she'd also be committing a criminal offense. 

The argument used to counter you: report the action taken against you to the proper authorities and have them deal with it existed since the code of Hammurabi (1750ish BC) or you may consider Draco (650 BC) as a more useful example since we know the court system that he created. So, for 2667 years or so, acting as a vigilante has been punished. That's a little longer than Riot has been around.

your arguments are still completely invalid because you're emphasizing the "don't fight back" too much based on real life scenarios.
this is a game, where you are physically safe. Yes people will be asses and verbally assault you, but that's why there's a report button after every game so those people can get filtered out eventually by suspensions.

Clearly you fail to understand the basic principles of psychology so I am done with you. The report button is NOT gratifying in the least, as you almost never get the ban notification (not that they don't get banned, you just don't get the satisfaction of knowing it). I will NEVER back down from a fight, virtual or no. I am not the kind of person that pusses out and lets people walk all over me. Riot definitively requires this kind of behavior, and therefore actively discriminates against any player with a distinctly alpha personality (obviously me).
